objdescid.compdate: c. 1785This drawing is dated to c. 1780 in Butlin 76 verso, but revised to c. 1785 in Martin Butlin, *William Blake 1757-1827*, Tate Gallery Collections: Volume Five (London: Tate Gallery, 1990) 55-56.

provenance.name: Rosenbach Museum and Library
provenance.note: Early history not known; William A. White by no later than 1905; acquired by A. S. W. Rosenbach shortly after White's death in 1927; acquired, by gift or bequest, by the Rosenbach Museum and Library in 1954.

desc.objtitle: Woman Playing a Harp, object 1 (Butlin 76 verso)

objnote.p: This is the upper half of a drawing. For the lower half, see *Lower Half of a Woman Playing a Harp*, Butlin 77 verso. The lower half of the drawing shows that the figure is seated. For the sketch on the recto, see *Joseph of Arimathea Preaching to the Inhabitants of Britain*.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Depicted from the waist up in the center of the composition, a single female figure with long, curly hair plays a harp that rests against her right shoulder. She wears a gown that emphasizes her ample breasts, and her mouth appears to be open. She may be singing. She may wear a ribbon or band in her hair. Facing forward and slightly left, she bends her raised right arm upward to pluck the harp's strings with bent fingers and palm facing forward. Her left arm is extended horizontally, slightly bent, and with spread fingers she plays the instrument with this hand as well. The upper frame of the harp, visible top left, appears to be ornamented or finely sculpted.

component.illusobjdesc: Depicted from the waist up in the center of the composition, a single female figure with long, curly hair plays a harp that rests against her right shoulder. She wears a gown that emphasizes her ample breasts, and her mouth appears to be open; she may be singing. She may wear a ribbon or band in her hair. Facing forward and slightly left, she bends her raised right arm upward to pluck the harp's strings with bent fingers and palm facing forward. Her left arm is extended horizontally, slightly bent, and with spread fingers she plays the instrument with this hand as well.

The single female figure in this drawing holds or rests a large harp against her right shoulder. She plays the strings of the instrument with both hands. The upper frame of the harp, visible top left, appears to be ornamented or finely sculpted.
